2.title: Eliezer Yudkowsky
2.clickbait: Cofounder, with Nick Bostrom, of the field of value alignment theory.

42.title: Nearest unblocked strategy
42.clickbait: If you patch an agent's preference framework to avoid an undesirable solution, what can you expect to happen?

47.title: Unforeseen maximum
47.clickbait: When you tell AI to produce world peace and it kills everyone.  (Okay, some SF writers saw that one coming.)

48.title: Patch resistance
48.clickbait: One does not simply solve the value alignment problem.

55.title: Value
55.clickbait: The word 'value' in the phrase 'value alignment' is a metasyntactic variable that indicates the speaker's future goals for intelligent life.

178.title: Arbital "tag" relationship
178.clickbait: Tags are a way to connect pages that share a common topic.

370.editSummary: reflecting the fact that we only have one type of mark now.
370.title: Arbital mark
370.clickbait: What is a mark on Arbital? When is it created? Why is it important?

597.title: Arbital page clickbait
597.clickbait: The text you are reading right now is clickbait.

17b.title: Arbital lens
17b.clickbait: A lens is a page that presents another page's content from a different angle.

1ln.editSummary: alias. note to self: come back and explain new requisites system.
1ln.title: Arbital requisites
1ln.clickbait: To understand a thing you often need to understand some other things.

1lw.title: Mathematics
1lw.clickbait: Mathematics is the study of numbers and other ideal objects that can be described by axioms.

1ly.title: Bayesian update
1ly.clickbait: Bayesian updating: the ideal way to change probabilistic beliefs based on evidence.

1rt.title: Arbital path
1rt.clickbait: Arbital path is a linear sequence of pages tailored specifically to teach a given concept to a user.

2c.title: Advanced agent properties
2c.clickbait: How smart does a machine intelligence need to be, for its niceness to become an issue?  "Advanced" is a broad term to cover cognitive abilities such that we'd need to start considering AI alignment.

2l.title: Advanced safety
2l.clickbait: An agent is *really* safe when it has the capacity to do anything, but chooses to do what the programmer wants.

2qp.title: Conservative concept boundary
2qp.clickbait: Given N example burritos, draw a boundary around what is a 'burrito' that is relatively simple and allows as few positive instances as possible.  Helps make sure the next thing generated is a burrito.

2r8.title: Mild optimization
2r8.clickbait: An AGI which, if you ask it to paint one car pink, just paints one car pink and doesn't tile the universe with pink-painted cars, because it's not trying *that* hard to max out its car-painting score.

2v.title: AI alignment
2v.clickbait: The great civilizational problem of creating artificially intelligent computer systems such that running them is a good idea.

2w.title: Edge instantiation
2w.clickbait: When you ask the AI to make people happy, and it tiles the universe with the smallest objects that can be happy.

2xd.title: Shutdown problem
2xd.clickbait: How to build an AGI that lets you shut it down, despite the obvious fact that this will interfere with whatever the AGI's goals are.

3d.title: Arbital
3d.clickbait: Arbital is the place for crowdsourced, intuitive math explanations.

3hs.title: Author's guide to Arbital
3hs.clickbait: How to write intuitive, flexible content on Arbital.

3n.title: Arbital "parent" relationship
3n.clickbait: Parent-child relationship between pages implies a strong, inseparable connection.

41k.title: Total alignment
41k.clickbait: We say that an advanced AI is "totally aligned" when it knows *exactly* which outcomes and plans are beneficial, with no further user input.

57b.title: Goodness estimate biaser
57b.clickbait: Some of the main problems in AI alignment can be seen as scenarios where actual goodness is likely to be systematically lower than a broken way of estimating goodness.
57b.text:
A "[55 goodness] estimate [statistical_bias biaser]" is a system setup or phenomenon that seems [6r foreseeably] likely to cause the actual goodness of some AI plan to be systematically lower than the AI's estimate of that plan's goodness.  We want the AI's estimate to be [statistically_unbiased unbiased].

Subtle and unsubtle [statistical_bias estimate-biasing] issues in machine learning are well-known and appear far short of [2c advanced agency]:

●  A machine learning algorithm's performance on the training data is not an unbiased estimate of its performance on the test data.  Some of what the algorithm seems to learn may be particular to noise in the training data.  This fitted noise will not be fitted within the test data.  So test performance is not just unequal to, but *systematically lower than,* training performance; if we were treating the training performance as an estimate of test performance, it would not be an [statistically_unbiased unbiased] estimate.

●  The [Winner's Curse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winner%27s_curse) from auction theory observes that if bidders have noise in their unbiased estimates of the auctioned item's value, then the *highest* bidder, who receives the item, is likely to have upward noise in their individually unbiased estimate.  (E.g., three bidders with Gaussian noise in their value estimates submit their true bids on an item whose true value is 1.0; the winning bidder is likely to have bid more than 1.0.)

The analogous [Optimizer's Curse](https://faculty.fuqua.duke.edu/~jes9/bio/The_Optimizers_Curse.pdf) observes that if we make locally unbiased but noisy estimates of the subjective expected utility of several plans, then selecting the plan with 'highest expected utility' is likely to have selected an estimate with upward noise.  Barring compensatory adjustments, this means that actual expected utility will be systematically lower than calculated expected utility, even if all expected utility estimates are individually unbiased.  Worse, if we have 10 plans whose expected utility can be unbiasedly estimated with low noise, and 10 plans whose expected utility can be unbiasedly estimated with high noise, then selecting the plan with apparently highest expected utility favors the noisiest estimates!

We can see many of the alleged foreseeable difficulties in [2v AI alignment] as involving similar forces that produce systematic downward biases in what we see as actual or intended [55 goodness], compared to an AI's estimate of goodness:

●  [2w] suggests that if we take an imperfect or incomplete learned criterion of value, then looking for the *maximum* or *extreme* of that value criterion is much more likely than usual to magnify the imperfections (because of [fragile_value fragility of value], plus the Optimizer's Curse) or destroy whatever aspects of value the AI didn't learn about (because optimizing a subset of properties is liable to set all other properties to extreme values).

We can see this as implying both "The AI's apparent goodness in non-extreme cases is not an unbiased estimate of its goodness in extreme cases" and "If the AI learns its goodness estimator less than [41k perfectly], the AI's estimates of the goodness of its best plans will systematically overestimate what we see as the actual goodness.

●  [42] generally, and especially over [instrumental_incorrigibility instrumentally convergent incorrigibility], suggests that if there are naturally-arising AI behaviors we see as bad (e.g. routing around [2xd shutdown]), there may emerge a pseudo-adversarial selection of best strategies that happen to route around our attempted [48 patches] to those problems.  E.g., the AI constructs an environmental subagent to continue carrying on its goals, while cheerfully obeying 'the letter of the law' with respect to allowing its current hardware to be shut down.  This pseudo-adversarial selection (though obviously the AI does not actually have a goal of thwarting us or selecting low-goodness strategies per se) again implies that operational goodness is likely to be systematically lower than the AI's partially-learned estimate of goodness; again to an [6q increasing degree] as the AI becomes [9f smarter] and [47 searches a wider policy space].

[2r8 Mild optimization] and [2qp conservative strategies] can be seen as proposals to 'regularize' powerful optimization in a way that decreases the degree to which goodness in training / AI-estimated goodness is a biased (over)estimate of goodness in execution / human-intended goodness.

6q.title: Context disaster
6q.clickbait: Some possible designs cause your AI to behave nicely while developing, and behave a lot less nicely when it's smarter.

6r.title: Methodology of foreseeable difficulties
6r.clickbait: Building a nice AI is likely to be hard enough, and contain enough gotchas that won't show up in the AI's early days, that we need to foresee problems coming in advance.

9f.title: Cognitive uncontainability
9f.clickbait: 'Cognitive uncontainability' is when we can't hold all of an agent's possibilities inside our own minds.
